problem.script:
from mitxgraders import *
grader_1 = MatrixGrader( answers='[1, 2]', max_array_dim=1 # this is the default, so we did not really need to set it )
grader_2 = MatrixGrader( answers='[1, 2]', max_array_dim=2 # students may enter vectors or matrices )
problem.p: This pair of graders is intended to display how MatrixGrader treats vectors, single-row matrices, and single-column matrices as different objects. The problems are identical, except that the second problem allows entry-by-entry matrix input.

ul.li:
Correct answers:
[1, 2]
trans([1, 2]), transpose does nothing to vectors
[[1, 0], [0, 1]] * [1, 2]
[1,2] * [[1, 0], [0, 1]]

problem.p: Here, we use a MathJax preprocessor to display vectors as columns rather than rows (the default display from AsciiMath). This is an option that can be turned on or off inside the preprocessor.

In "real" problems, we strongly recommend disallowing entry-by-entry matrix input (by default, this is disallowed) unless it is needed, to avoid potential confusion between [1, 2] and [[1], [2]] (or [1, 2] and [[1, 2]] with the column vector option turned off).
